node.title: On Rikers, Brooklyn Man Becomes Latest Detainee to Die in Custody
node.alt: A Brooklyn man died at Rikers Island after suffering a medical emergency.
node.description: The death of a 16th man who had been held in New York City custody came as the Department of Correction grapples with a crisis at the Rikers Island jail complex.
node.content: ["A Brooklyn man who was being held on Rikers Island suffered a medical emergency and died on Tuesday night, becoming the latest detainee to die in New York City\u2019s troubled main jail complex as city officials struggle to restore order there.", "William Brown, 55, went into distress and died shortly before midnight on Tuesday, officials said. The cause of his death remains under investigation.", "Mr. Brown was the 16th person to die after being held in the city\u2019s jail system since January, making this year the deadliest since 2013, when the jail population was twice what it is today.", "\u201cI am devastated to know that another person entrusted in our care has passed away,\u201d Jails Commissioner Vincent N. Schiraldi said in a statement on Wednesday. ", "Mr. Brown was being held at the Anna M. Kross Center, the largest jail facility on Rikers Island, when an officer on tour found him unresponsive on the floor and called for medical assistance at 10:42 p.m., according to an internal preliminary report. Seven minutes later, medical staff arrived and called for additional help. Emergency medical responders arrived roughly 30 minutes later, but Mr. Brown could not be revived.", "His death comes as New York City\u2019s correction agency is dealing with two crises \u2014 a pandemic and a staffing emergency in which a third of the uniformed work force has been out \u2014 that have disrupted the basic operations of the jails and caused shortcomings in medical and mental health care.", "\u201cThe carceral system is deadly, it\u2019s violent, and we have a staff crisis,\u201d said Tina Luongo, the attorney in charge of the Legal Aid Society\u2019s criminal defense practice. \u201cIf this is not a rude awakening that we need to take a different approach, then I don\u2019t know what we are going to do as a city.\u201d", "Of this year\u2019s deaths, 14 have occurred in city jails. Two happened in hospitals soon after incarcerated people were released.", "Mr. Brown had been at Rikers on robbery charges since Nov. 14, records show.", "On Friday, Malcolm Boatwright, a 28-year-old man with autism, died at the Bellevue Hospital Center after having a seizure at the jail the day before. He had been detained on Rikers for about a month on sexual abuse charges before his death. An official cause of death is still pending."]
